questions.question: Question 1: What is the chromosome number of a partial hydatidiform mole?
questions.explanation:
Partial hydatidiform mole has a 69XXY or 69XYY karyotype. 442 
Sold by @itachibot Hydatiform mole belongs to the benign group of gestational trophoblastic diseases (GTD). It is an 
abnormality in chorionic villi making them partly proliferative and degenerative, thereby resulting 
in the formation of multiple small cysts. Based on the portion of the chorionic villi involved, they 
could be complete (diffused) or partial (focal)

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following statements is false regarding hydatidiform moles?

options.a: Complete moles show diffuse trophoblastic hyperplasia
options.b: Fetal tissue is seen in partial mole
options.c: Early USG is sensitive for partial moles
options.d: Complete moles have higher malignant potential

questions.explanation:
Early ultrasonography is not highly sensitive in a patient with partial molar pregnancy. However, 
USG features like thickened, multicystic placenta along with fetal tissue or even a fetus may be 
seen. Hydatidiform mole or molar pregnancy is an abnormal condition of the placenta. It is 
characterized by trophoblastic proliferation and stromal edema. They are classified into complete 
and partial moles based on the absence or presence of embryonic elements. Pathogenesis of complete and partial moles are as follows: 443 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following is not associated with the development of a hydatidiform mole?
questions.explanation: Vitamin A deficiency, not Vitamin C deficiency is a risk factor for hydatidiform mole. Risk factors for hydatidiform mole are: • Maternal age - pregnancy in teenage and women >35 years • Previous history of gestational trophoblastic disease • Dietary deficiency - vitamin A deficiency, inadequate protein and animal fat intake • AB blood group.

questions.question:
Question 4: A 20-year-old primigravida with bleeding PV was diagnosed to have a complete hydatidiform 
mole. Which of the following is not true in this condition?

options.d: Serum free T4 levels normalise after uterine evacuation

questions.explanation:
Theca lutein cysts are rare in partial molar pregnancy, but may be seen in 25-30% of patients with 
complete molar pregnancy. Serum -hCG levels are elevated more than expected for gestational age in a complete mole. The sensitivity of most hCG tests is set to the pregnancy hCG range. An excessive -hCG hormone 
causes an oversaturation of the test assay giving a false negative UPT. This is called the hook 
effect. The thyrotropin-like effects of hCG frequently cause serum free-T4 levels to be elevated which 
normalize after uterine evacuation.

questions.question:
Question 5: A pregnant woman at 12 weeks of gestation presents with spotting PV, hyperemesis, and 
lower abdominal pain for the past 2 days. USG done is shown below. What is the most 
probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
444 
Sold by @itachibot The given clinical scenario and USG showing snowstorm appearance is suggestive of a complete 
mole. The snowstorm appearance is due to an echogenic uterine mass that has numerous anechoic 
cystic spaces. Fetus and amniotic sac are absent. Investigations for molar pregnancy are: • USG - shows snowstorm appearance • Serum  hCG - elevated to >2 MoM (multiples of median) for corresponding gestational age • Histological examination of products of conception Snowstorms in radiology: • Complete hydatiform mole (ultrasound) • Extracapsular breast implant rupture (ultrasound) • Carcinoma thyroid - pulmonary metastases (chest X-ray).

questions.question:
Question 6: A primigravida at 12 weeks of gestation presented with complaints of the expulsion of 
grape-like vesicles PV for the past day. A diagnosis of molar pregnancy was made on USG 
examination. Incidentally, the following adnexal lesion was also noted. What is the lesion? 436 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given USG image shows theca lutein cysts in the ovary. These cysts are usually seen in 
patients with complete molar pregnancies. They are usually bilateral and are also seen in multiple 
pregnancies. Theca lutein cysts result from the overstimulation of lutein elements by massive amounts of 
hCG. The cystic fluid is rich in chorionic gonadotropin, estrogen, and progesterone.

questions.question:
Question 7: A patient who was treated for molar pregnancy came for follow-up after 4 months. Her USG 
revealed a large, twisted theca lutein cyst. How will you manage this patient?
questions.explanation:
Untwisting of the cyst is the only management in an asymptomatic patient with a twisted theca 
lutein cyst. Laparoscopic oophorectomy is done only when there is associated extensive necrosis or 
hemorrhage. Theca-lutein cysts regress within 2 months after pregnancy evacuation, and hence expectant 
management is preferred in uncomplicated cases. If the cysts are symptomatic, they can be 
aspirated trans-abdominally under ultrasound guidance.

questions.question:
Question 8: A pregnant woman at 14 weeks of gestation complains of excessive vomiting and mild vaginal 
bleeding for 2 weeks. On examination, fundal height corresponds to 16 weeks and fetal heart 
sounds are absent. USG shows a snowstorm appearance and no fetus. What is the best step of 
management?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of molar pregnancy which is managed by suction and 
evacuation, regardless of uterine size. If the cervix is unfavorable, slow dilatation is done with vaginal PGE1. Volume resuscitation with 
IV fluids and parenteral antibiotics can be given as supportive therapy. Blood transfusion is done 445 
Sold by @itachibot if the patient is anaemic. Intraoperative sonography is recommended to help ensure that the uterine cavity has been 
emptied. Indication for hysterectomy in molar pregnancy: • Women who have completed their family • Age >40 years • Uncontrolled hemorrhage • Perforation during surgical evacuation.

questions.question:
Question 9: A 36-year-old woman underwent suction evacuation for a hydatidiform mole. Which of the 
following statements is true regarding her follow-up with -hCG estimation?

options.b: Twice weekly estimation for a month following evacuation
options.c: Monthly follow-up for 6 months after three consecutive normal values
options.d: After 6 months of follow-up, regular yearly estimation should be done

questions.explanation:
In the given scenario, the patient is followed up with serum  hCG every month for 6 months. Follow-up after the termination of molar pregnancy is done with serum  hCG levels. During the 
follow-up period, pregnancy must be avoided as it might interfere with the  hCG levels. The initial -hCG level is obtained within 48 hours after evacuation and used as a baseline. It is measured weekly till it becomes negative, and three consecutive normal values are obtained. 
This normally happens in 4-8 weeks. After this,  hCG levels are measured monthly for 6 months. Women who undergo chemotherapy 
must be followed up for 1 year.

questions.question: Question 10: Which of the following are complications that can be seen in a patient with molar pregnancy?
questions.explanation:
Thyrotoxicosis is seen as a complication of molar pregnancy, not hypothyroidism. Complications in molar pregnancy include: • Immediate: • Early-onset pre-eclampsia - molar placentas produce more antiangiogenic proteins than normal 
placentas. • Thyrotoxicosis - as  component of hCG mimics TSH and causes thyroid storm • Acute pulmonary insufficiency - due to embolization of trophoblastic cells • Electrolyte imbalance i.e., hypokalemia, hyponatremia - due to hyperemesis caused by  hCG • Shock - hemorrhage due to the separation of vesicles and intra-peritoneal haemorrhage • Disseminated intravascular coagulation • Late: Choriocarcinoma. 446 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 11: Gestational trophoblastic neoplasm does not include
questions.explanation:
A partial mole is not a gestational trophoblastic neoplasm (GTN). Gestational trophoblastic disease (GTD) is the term used to describe a group of tumors due to 
abnormal trophoblast proliferation. Malignant forms of GTD are termed gestational trophoblastic 
neoplasia (GTN). Modified WHO Classification of GTD Molar Pregnancies 
Trophoblastic tumors Choriocarcinoma (malignant) 
Placental site trophoblastic t

mole (malignant)

questions.question:
Question 12: All of the following are non-molar trophoblastic neoplasms except  
.
questions.explanation: Invasive mole is a molar trophoblastic neoplasm.

questions.question:
Question 13: What is the most common non-metastatic gestational trophoblastic neoplasia that develops 
following hydatidiform mole?
questions.explanation:
Chorioadenoma destruens or invasive mole is the most common non-metastatic GTN that follows 
hydatidiform moles. Almost all invasive moles arise from partial or complete moles. Invasive mole is characterized by extensive tissue invasion by trophoblast and whole villi. They 
can penetrate deep into the myometrium, peritoneum, parametrium, or vaginal vault. They are 
locally aggressive and do not usually metastasize. 447 
Sold by @itachibot The most common GTN following term pregnancy or miscarriage is choriocarcinoma.

questions.question:
Question 14: Which of the following are risk factors for malignant change in a patient with molar 
pregnancy?
questions.explanation:
Maternal age >40 years, -hCG levels >100,000 mIU/mL and grand multiparity are risk 
factors for malignant change in a patient with molar pregnancy. Risk factors for malignant change are: • Patient's age  40 years or <20 years • Parity 3 • Uterine size >20 weeks • Previous history of molar pregnancy • Complete moles have 15-20% risk of malignant transformation, partial moles have 1-5% risk • Serum  hCG >1,00,000 mIU/mL • Large theca lutein cysts >6 cm in diameter Post-evacuation uterine sonographic surveillance can be used as a predictor of subsequent 
neoplasia. Findings indicative of malignant transformation are: • Suburethral nodules • Myometrial nodules • Hypervascularity.

questions.question: Question 15: All of the following can be indicators of choriocarcinoma except:

options.a: Increased number of theca lutein cysts

questions.explanation:
448 
Sold by @itachibot Increased number of theca lutein cysts is not an indicator of choriocarcinoma. Increased 
size or persistence of theca lutein cysts indicates choriocarcinoma. Plateau of high serum -hCG level for four measurements for 3 weeks is an indicator 
of choriocarcinoma. Risk factors for malignant change are: • Molar pregnancy - complete moles have 15-20% risk, partial moles have 1-5% risk • Patient's age  40 years or <20 years • Parity 3 • Serum  hCG >1,00,000 IU/mL • Uterine size >20 weeks • Previous history of molar pregnancy • Large theca lutein cysts >6 cm in diameter Post-evacuation uterine sonographic surveillance can be used as a predictor of subsequent 
neoplasia. Findings indicative of malignant transformation are: • Suburethral nodules • Myometrial nodules • Hypervascularity.

questions.question:
Question 16: A patient with a history of molar pregnancy was treated with suction and evacuation. Which 
method of contraception would you not recommend for her?
questions.explanation:
IUCD (intrauterine contraceptive device) is contraindicated in this patient as the uterus is friable 
and can cause further bleeding. Accepted methods of contraception after suction evacuation in molar pregnancy include: • Oral contraceptive pills • Depot medroxyprogesterone acetate • Barrier methods.

questions.question: Question 17: What will be the WHO score in a patient with low-risk gestational trophoblastic neoplasia?
questions.explanation:
Low-risk GTN has a WHO score of 0 to 6. High-risk GTN has a WHO score of  7. Features

questions.question:
Question 18: A patient was diagnosed to have choriocarcinoma two years post-evacuation of molar 
pregnancy. Which of the following is the most common site of metastasis in this patient?
questions.explanation:
The common sites of metastases of choriocarcinoma are in the following order: • Lungs - most common • Vagina - second most common • Vulva • •idneys • Liver • Ovaries • Brain • Bowel Lung metastases present as cannon-ball or snowstorm appearance on chest X-ray. Vaginal 
metastases present as purplish sub-urethral nodules.

questions.question:
Question 19: A case of gestational trophoblastic neoplasm is detected to have metastasis in the lungs. It is 
considered as stage  
.
questions.explanation:
Metastases in the lungs are considered stage III GTN (gestational trophoblastic neoplasia) in 
FIGO classification. International Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics (FIGO) staging for GTN is as follows: The chest X-ray below shows lung metastasis - stage III GTN. Description Stag 
e I 
GTN confined to theuterus 450 
Sold by @itachibot Stag 
Description 
e II 
GTN extends outside of the u 
terus but is limited to thegeni 
talstructures(adnexa, vagina, 
broad ligament) III 
GTN extends to thelungs, wit 
h or without known genital tr 
act involvement IV 
Allothermetastatic sites i.e. ki 
dney, liver, brain, bowel, etc. Gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN) refers to the aggressive invasion of the endometrium 
and myometrium by trophoblast cells. It includes invasive mole, gestational choriocarcinoma, 
placental site trophoblastic tumors, and epithelioid trophoblastic tumors. GTN is diagnosed based 
on elevated -hCG levels. FIGO criteria for diagnosis of GTN: • Persistence of -hCG level plateau in 4 measurements for 3 weeks or longer • Rise in -hCG levels in 3 or more consecutive measurements done weekly, over a period of 2 
weeks or longer • Elevated -hCG level for 6 months or more • Histologic diagnosis of choriocarcinoma Treatment for low-risk disease is chemotherapy with methotrexate, while those with high-risk 
disease are treated with etoposide, methotrexate, and dactinomycin alternating with 
cyclophosphamide and vincristine (EMA/CO) chemotherapy. 451 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 20: A 43-year-old woman presents with complaints of hemoptysis, vaginal bleeding, and 
abdominal pain for 7 days. Chest X-ray is shown below. Transabdominal USG revealed a solid 
mass occupying the uterus which was found to be choriocarcinoma with a WHO score of 8. 440 
Sold by @itachibot How would you manage this patient?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of high-risk (WHO) stage III choriocarcinoma which is 
treated with EMA-CO regimen. The given X-ray shows numerous, dense, bilateral metastatic 
nodules, of varying sizes indicative of lung metastases. The components of EMA-CO are: • Etoposide • Methotrexate • Actinomycin D • Cyclophosphamide • Oncovin i.e. vincristine Option A: PSTT (placental-site trophoblastic tumor) and ETT (epithelioid trophoblastic tumors) 
are treated by hysterectomy only, as they are resistant to chemotherapy. Option B: R-CHOP regimen is used for B-cell non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. Option D: MVAC regimen is used for advanced bladder carcinoma. Risk

Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 21: Placental-site trophoblastic tumor arises from  
.
questions.explanation:
Placental-site trophoblastic tumor arises from implantation site intermediate trophoblast. As 
syncytiotrophoblastic cells are generally absent in this site, it is composed mainly 
of cytotrophoblastic cells. Patients with placental site trophoblastic tumors present with vaginal bleeding and modestly 
elevated serum -hCG levels. Local invasion into the myometrium and lymphatics occurs. 
Hysterectomy is the preferred treatment.

questions.question:
Question 22: A 26-year-old woman with a history of early miscarriage presented with amenorrhoea. Her 
serum beta hCG levels were persistently low and USG revealed a single solid mass in the 
uterine fundus. Histopathological examination of the biopsy showed abundant intermediate 
trophoblastic cells. What is the next step of management?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of placental-site trophoblastic tumor (PSTT). 
Hysterectomy is the treatment of choice because they are locally invasive tumors and resistant to 
chemotherapy. PSTT is a rare tumor arising from intermediate trophoblastic of the placental bed. Patients with 
placental site trophoblastic tumors present with vaginal bleeding and modestly elevated serum 
-hCG levels. They produce variant forms of hCG. 453 
Sold by @itachibot Anemia in Pregnancy
